elements.content: Two new coordination polymers [Ca3(bta)2(H2O)8]·3H2O (1) and Ba3(bta)2(H2O)8 (2) were obtained by self-assembly of the corresponding metal carbonate with a flexible tripodal ligand, benzene-1,3,5-triacetic acid (H3bta), and their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The results revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄ with a = 8.3045(10) Å, b = 10.4883(10) Å, c = 11.0184(16) Å, α = 102.703(3)°, β = 100.001(4)°, γ = 108.842(7)°, V = 854.36(18) Å3, and Z = 1; compound 2 is in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a = 23.4363(8) Å, b = 6.9782(3) Å, c = 21.7150(8) Å, β = 111.4480(10)°, V = 3305.4(2) Å3, and Z = 4. Complexes 1 and 2 have two-dimensional network structures, and each bta3- ligand coordinates to Ca(II) or Ba(II) atoms using two of three carboxylate groups adopting different coordination modes:  μ3-η2:η2-bridging and μ2-η2:η-bridging coordination modes in 1 or μ3-η:η2-bridging and μ3-η2:η1-bridging coordination modes in 2. The noncoordinated carboxylic group forms hydrogen bonds with an adjacent network to generate a three-dimensional structure. The luminescence properties of 1 and 2 were investigated and found that the complexes showed photoluminescence in the solid state at room temperature.

The results revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄ with a = 8.3045(10) Å, b = 10.4883(10) Å, c = 11.0184(16) Å, α = 102.703(3)°, β = 100.001(4)°, γ = 108.842(7)°, V = 854.36(18) Å3, and Z = 1; compound 2 is in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a = 23.4363(8) Å, b = 6.9782(3) Å, c = 21.7150(8) Å, β = 111.4480(10)°, V = 3305.4(2) Å3, and Z = 4. The noncoordinated carboxylic group forms hydrogen bonds with an adjacent network to generate a three-dimensional structure. The luminescence properties of 1 and 2 were investigated and found that the complexes showed photoluminescence in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Self-assembled coordination polymers containing transition metal ions and organic bridging ligands have been rapidly developed in recent years due to their fascinating molecular topologies and crystal-packing motifs along with potential applications as functional materials. Many efforts have been devoted to the selection or design of suitable ligands containing certain features, such as flexibility, versatile binding modes, and the ability to form hydrogen bonds. Carboxylate-containing ligands have attracted much attention because of the diversity of the binding modes of the carboxylate group. To now, extensive works have been carried out by using carboxylate-containing ligands, for example, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H3btc), 4,4‘,4‘ ‘-benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tribenzoic acid (H3btb), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (p-H2bdc), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (m-H2bdc), and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4btec). In these reports, most of the bridging ligands used in construction of the porous frameworks are rigid, since the carboxylate groups in these ligands are attached to the central aromatic ring directly. Coordination polymers assembled by metal salts with flexible carboxylate-containing ligands are not well done to now, possibly due to the difficulties in predicting the resulted framework structures. In addition, as compared to the reports of d-block transition metal polymers, alkaline earth polymeric complexes are less common. Herein, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of two novel two-dimensional (2D) coordination complexes, [Ca3(bta)2(H2O)8]·3H2O (1) and Ba3(bta)2(H2O)8 (2), where bta3- is a flexible tripodal ligand, benzene-1,3,5-triacetate. There is a methylene group between each carboxylate group and the central benzene; thus, there are different conformations when the bta3- reacts with metal salts as demonstrated in the previous studies for the imidazole-containing tripodal ligands such as 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, while in the cases of rigid ligands such as btc, btb, etc., there are no such great conformational changes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Self-assembled coordination polymers containing transition metal ions and organic bridging ligands have been rapidly developed in recent years due to their fascinating molecular topologies and crystal-packing motifs along with potential applications as functional materials. Many efforts have been devoted to the selection or design of suitable ligands containing certain features, such as flexibility, versatile binding modes, and the ability to form hydrogen bonds. Carboxylate-containing ligands have attracted much attention because of the diversity of the binding modes of the carboxylate group. To now, extensive works have been carried out by using carboxylate-containing ligands, for example, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H3btc), 4,4‘,4‘‘-benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tribenzoic acid (H3btb), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (p-H2bdc), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (m-H2bdc), and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4btec). In these reports, most of the bridging ligands used in construction of the porous frameworks are rigid, since the carboxylate groups in these ligands are attached to the central aromatic ring directly. Coordination polymers assembled by metal salts with flexible carboxylate-containing ligands are not well done to now, possibly due to the difficulties in predicting the resulted framework structures. In addition, as compared to the reports of d-block transition metal polymers, alkaline earth polymeric complexes are less common. Herein, we report the synthesis and structural characterization of two novel two-dimensional (2D) coordination complexes, [Ca3(bta)2(H2O)8]⋅3H2O (1) and Ba3(bta)2(H2O)8 (2), where bta3- is a flexible tripodal ligand, benzene-1,3,5-triacetate. There is a methylene group between each carboxylate group and the central benzene; thus, there are different conformations when the bta3- reacts with metal salts as demonstrated in the previous studies for the imidazole-containing tripodal ligands such as 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, while in the cases of rigid ligands such as btc, btb, etc., there are no such great conformational changes.

elements.content: General Methods. All commercially available chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. C and H analyses were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 Fourier transform (FT)-IR spectrophotometer by using KBr disks. TGA measurements were performed with a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The luminescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. In the measurements of the emission and excitation spectra, the pass width was 5.0 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Methods. All commercially available chemicals were of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. C and H analyses were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Vector22 Fourier transform (FT)-IR spectrophotometer by using KBr disks. TGA measurements were performed with a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The luminescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. In the measurements of the emission and excitation spectra, the pass width was 5.0 nm.

elements.content:
Preparation of the Complexes. The compound H3bta was prepared according to the method reported in the literature.

[Ca 3 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 8 ] · 3H 2 O (1) . The complex 1 was synthesized by reaction between H3bta (25.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) and calcium carbonate (15.1 mg, 0.15 mmol) in water (7.5 mL). After filtration, pale yellow block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow diffusion of acetone into the clear filtrate for several days in 60% yield. Anal. calcd for C24H40O23Ca3 (816.80):  C, 35.29; H, 4.94. Found:  C, 35.41; H, 5.11. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3354m (br), 1675w, 1538s, 1427m, 1403m, 1322w, 1276w, 1249w, 1142w, 962w, 935w, 764m, 687m, 586w, 554w. The TGA data of 1 exhibited the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules occurred between 40 and 170 °C, and no further weight loss was observed up to 470 °C.

Colorless needle crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained in 85% yield after several weeks. Anal. calcd for C24H34Ba3O20 (1054.53):  C, 27.34; H, 3.25. Found:  C, 27.26; H, 3.37. The TGA data of 2 exhibited the loss of coordinated water molecules occurred before 115 °C, and no further weight loss was observed up to 450 °C.

elements.content: Crystallography. The X-ray diffraction measurements for complexes 1 and 2 were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The structure of 1 was solved by direct methods using SIR92, and the structure of 2 was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97. Complexes 1 and 2 were expanded using Fourier techniques. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically. Hydrogen atoms of water were found in the difference Fourier map directly. All calculations were carried out on a SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in Table . Selected bond length and angles are listed in Table . Further details are provided in the Supporting Information.

Crystal Structure Description. In the previously reported complexes Ca(Hbtc)·2H2O and Ba(Hbtc)(H2O)2·0.5H2O, the ligand H3btc is only partial deprotonated. While the results of single-crystal X-ray analyses of complexes 1 and 2 reveal that the H3bta ligands are completely deprotonated, which agrees well with the IR data since no strong absorption peaks around 1700 cm-1 for −COOH were observed in IR spectra of 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Crystal Structure Description. In the previously reported complexes Ca(Hbtc)⋅2H2O and Ba(Hbtc)(H2O)2⋅0.5H2O, the ligand H3btc is only partial deprotonated. While the results of single-crystal X-ray analyses of complexes 1 and 2 reveal that the H3bta ligands are completely deprotonated, which agrees well with the IR data since no strong absorption peaks around 1700 cm-1 for -COOH were observed in IR spectra of 1 and 2.

elements.content: In complex 1, there are two crystallographically independent Ca atom centers (Ca2 sits on the inversion center) in the structure, each having a different coordination number and coordination environment as illustrated in Figure . Ca1 is coordinated by seven O atoms:  two (O1A and O4A) from two different carboxylate groups, two (O1 and O2) from one carboxylate group, and three (O7, O8, and O9) from three water molecules. Ca2 is coordinated by eight O atoms:  two (O2 and O2A) from two different carboxylate groups, four (O3A, O4A, O3B, and O4B) from two different carboxylate groups, and two (O10 and O10A) from two water molecules. The coordination environment of Ca1 can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid. Two coordinated water molecules of O7 and O9 occupy the apical positions with a trans angle of 176.63(11)°. The Ca1 atom lies on the pentagonal plane since the deviation is less than 0.01 Å. The Ca1−O bond distances range from 2.301(3) to 2.492(3) Å (Table ), which are similar to those observed in other calcium carboxylate complexes. The Ca1 and Ca1B bridged by O1 and O1A (Figure a) have a separation of 3.9033(14) Å, which is close to those reported for binuclear complexes with Ca−Ca distances of 3.860(2) and 3.891(4) Å. The distance between the Ca and the Ca atoms indicates the existence of Ca···Ca interactions in this complex. The coordination environment of centrosymmetric Ca2 can be described as a distorted square anti-prism. Two O atoms (O2 and O4A) are engaged in bridging Ca1 and Ca2 with a separation of 4.0192(8) Å between the Ca1 and the Ca2.

elements.content: The calcium atoms and bridging oxygen atoms form an infinite zigzag chain since the angles of Ca1A−Ca2−Ca1 and Ca2−Ca1−Ca1B are 180 and 118.72(3)°, respectively (Figure a). The distance between Ca1A and Ca1B is 10.488 Å corresponding to the length of the b-axis. These one-dimensional (1D) chains are bridged by a bta3- ligand to generate a 2D network on the ab plane (Figure b). Each bta3- ligand binds to five calcium atoms with a cis, cis, cis conformation with two of three carboxylate groups adopting μ3-η2:η2-bridging (each oxygen atom coordinates to two metal atoms, and the carboxylic group coordinates to three metal atoms) and μ2-η2:η1-bridging (one oxygen atom connects two metal ions, the other connects one metal atom, and the carboxylic group coordinates to two metal atoms) coordination modes (Scheme ). Lattice water molecules occupied the voids of the 2D network and served as receptors or donors of the O−H···O hydrogen bond (Figure S1). The noncoordinated carboxylate group of the bta3- ligand offers an oxygen atom to form an O−H···O hydrogen bond (O···O, 2.669(6) Å; O−H···O, 173°) with the coordinated water molecule of an adjacent layer to generate a three-dimensional (3D) structure (Figure S1). The hydrogen bonding data are summarized in Table . The polymeric structure of complex 1 is also stabilized by face-to-face π−π interactions since the centroid−centroid distance between the two nearest parallel benzene ring planes of two adjacent layers is 3.59 Å.

The distance between Ca1A and Ca1B is 10.488 Å corresponding to the length of the b-axis. These one-dimensional (1D) chains are bridged by a bta3- ligand to generate a 2D network on the ab plane (Figure b). Each bta3- ligand binds to five calcium atoms with a cis, cis, cis conformation with two of three carboxylate groups adopting μ3-η2:η2-bridging (each oxygen atom coordinates to two metal atoms, and the carboxylic group coordinates to three metal atoms) and μ2-η2:η1-bridging (one oxygen atom connects two metal ions, the other connects one metal atom, and the carboxylic group coordinates to two metal atoms) coordination modes (Scheme ). Lattice water molecules occupied the voids of the 2D network and served as receptors or donors of the O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (Figure S1). The noncoordinated carboxylate group of  the bta3- ligand offers an oxygen atom to form an O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (O⋅⋅⋅O, 2.669(6) Å; O-H⋅⋅⋅O, 173°) with the coordinated water molecule of an adjacent layer to generate a three-dimensional (3D) structure (Figure S1). The hydrogen bonding data are summarized in Table . The polymeric structure of complex 1 is also stabilized by face-to-face π-π interactions since the centroid-centroid distance between the two nearest parallel benzene ring planes of two adjacent layers is 3.59 Å.

To evaluate the effect of metal ion during the construction of the supramolecular architectures, BaCO3, instead of CaCO3, was employed to react with H3bta ligand to give 2. Complex 2 has the same metal/ligand ratio as that in 1. In complex 2, the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Ba atom centers (Figure ) with different coordination environments. The barium atoms are both eight-coordinated with an O8 donor set:  six from six different carboxylate groups of four bta3- ligands, two from water molecules for Ba1; two (O1 and O3A) from two different carboxylate groups, two (O3B and O4B) from one carboxylate group, and four (O7, O8, O9, and O10) from four water molecules for Ba2. The coordination geometry around the Ba1 atom is a distorted hexagonal bipyramid with the deviation of the hexagonal plane about 0.17 Å, and the Ba1 atom lies on the hexagonal plane. O4A and O4B occupy the apical position with a Ba1−O bond length of 2.6820(19) Å and a trans angle of 163.06(10)° (Table ). The coordination geometry around the Ba2 atom is approximately bicapped trigonal prism in which O1, O7, and O4B form the top plane of the trigonal prism, and the bottom plane is completed by O9, O3A, and O3B, while O8 and O10 capped quadrilateral face formed by O1, O7, O3A, O9 and O7, O3A, O3B, O4B, respectively. The Ba2−O bond lengths range from 2.665(2) to 2.828(2) Å. The Ba−O bond lengths are similar with those reported in the complex {[Ba2(L)(HO)5]Cl}∞ [where L is 1,3,5-tris(sulfomethyl)benzene].

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, one Ba1 and two Ba2 atoms form a Ba3 unit. In complex 1, the calcium atoms are bridged by two oxygen atoms (Figure a), while in complex 2, the barium atoms are bridged by two or three oxygen atoms (Figure a). It may be attributed to different radii of the metal atoms. The barium atom (Ba1) is bridged to two barium atoms (Ba2 and Ba2A) via three oxygen atoms, one from a coordinated water molecule and two from two bta3- ligands. The corresponding Ba−O distances range from 2.6820(19) to 2.949(2) Å, and the Ba1−O−Ba2 bond angles range from 96.75(7) to 102.01(6) °. These Ba3 units are bridged by two oxygen atoms from two bta3- ligands to generate a wavelike 1D chain [the angles of Ba2A−Ba1−Ba2 and Ba1−Ba2−Ba2B are 135.345(9) and 120.252(7)°, respectively]. The corresponding Ba2−O3A bond length is 2.786(2), and the Ba2−O3A−Ba2B bond angle is 105.22(7)°. The Ba···Ba distances [Ba1···Ba2 distance is 4.2835(3) Å and Ba2···Ba2B distance is 4.3317(4) Å] are close to the sum of van der Waals radii (4.28 Å) but are longer than those observed in complex [{Ba2(OOCC6H4SSC6H4COO)2(H2O)2}·0.5H2O] n . These wavelike 1D chains are bridged by a bta3- ligand to generate a 2D network on the ab plane (Figure b). Each bta3- ligand of 2 binds to five barium atoms with a cis, cis, cis conformation, and the carboxylic groups adopt μ3-η2:η2-bridging and μ3-η2:η1-bridging coordination modes (Scheme ). Because of the different coordination modes of bta3- ligand, the structures of 1 and 2 are very unlike. The carboxylate groups in 1 coordinated with the calcium atoms from the same Ca−O chain, and the resulting structure was a network with channels occupied by lattice water molecules (Figure S1), while the carboxylate group containing O1 in 2 coordinated with two Ba atoms from different Ba−O chains (Figure S2). In complex 2, the noncoordinated carboxylic group of the ligand offers oxygen atoms to form O−H···O hydrogen bonds [O···O 2.687(4), 2.701(4), 2.694(4), 2.627(4) Å; O−H···O 160(4), 155.90, 153.93, 166(4)°, Table ] with the coordinated water molecules of the adjacent layer. These hydrogen bonds lead the 2D layers to a 3D structure (Figure S3).

elements.content: Photoluminescent Properties of Complexes 1 and 2. Luminescent properties of Ca(II) and Ba(II) complexes are not well-studied at room temperature to now, although there are reports on the photoluminescent properties of calcium-containing or barium-containing inorganic materials. The photoluminescent properties of complexes 1 and 2 as well as H3bta ligand were studied in the solid state at room temperature. No clear luminescence was detected for H3bta ligand under the experimental conditions. In contrast to the H3bta ligand, the Ca(II) (1) and Ba(II) (2) complexes show violet-blue photoluminescence under the same conditions (Figure ). Complex 1 exhibits photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 417 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 354 nm. In the case of complex 2, a similar photoluminescence with the maximum emission at 413 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 354 nm was observed. In the reported alkaline earth metal complexes with crown ethers containing the 1,8-dioxyxanthone residue, the photoluminescence of the crown ether ligands was greatly enhanced by complexation of alkaline earth metal ions. Also, no clear emission was observed for trimellitic acid, but its cadmium(II) complex exhibited a strong photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 436 nm upon excitation at 328 nm. Therefore, the observed photoluminescence of complexes 1 and 2 was contributed by the coordination of alkaline earth metal ions to the bta ligands.

cln_elements.content:
Preparation of the Complexes. The compound H3bta was prepared according to the method reported in the literature.

[Ca 3 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 8 ] · 3H 2 O (1) . The complex 1 was synthesized by reaction between H3bta (25.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) and calcium carbonate (15.1 mg, 0.15 mmol) in water (7.5 mL). After filtration, pale yellow block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow diffusion of acetone into the clear filtrate for several days in 60% yield. Anal. calcd for C24H40O23Ca3 (816.80):  C, 35.29; H, 4.94. Found:  C, 35.41; H, 5.11. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3354m (br), 1675w, 1538s, 1427m, 1403m, 1322w, 1276w, 1249w, 1142w, 962w, 935w, 764m, 687m, 586w, 554w. The TGA data of 1 exhibited the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules occurred between 40 and 170 °C, and no further weight loss was observed up to 470 °C.

Ba 3 (bta) 2 (H 2 O) 8 (2) . The complex 2 was obtained by similar procedures to complex 1 using barium carbonate (29.6 mg, 0.15 mmol) instead of calcium carbonate to react with H3bta (25.2 mg, 0.1 mmol). Colorless needle crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained in 85% yield after several weeks. Anal. calcd for C24H34Ba3O20 (1054.53):  C, 27.34; H, 3.25. Found:  C, 27.26; H, 3.37. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3318m (br), 2909w, 1650m, 1555s, 1460w, 1425m, 1392s, 1339w, 1280m, 1199w, 1000w, 928w, 897w, 763m, 694m, 675m, 627m, 579m. The TGA data of 2 exhibited the loss of coordinated water molecules occurred before 115 °C, and no further weight loss was observed up to 450 °C.

Photoluminescent Properties of Complexes 1 and 2. Luminescent properties of Ca(II) and Ba(II) complexes are not well-studied at room temperature to now, although there are reports on the photoluminescent properties of calcium-containing or barium-containing inorganic materials. The photoluminescent properties of complexes 1 and 2 as well as H3bta ligand were studied in the solid state at room temperature. No clear luminescence was detected for H3bta ligand under the experimental conditions. In contrast to the H3bta ligand, the Ca(II) (1) and Ba(II) (2) complexes show violet-blue photoluminescence under the same conditions (Figure ). Complex 1 exhibits photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 417 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 354 nm. In the case of complex 2, a similar photoluminescence with the maximum emission at 413 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 354 nm was observed. In the reported alkaline earth metal complexes with crown ethers containing the 1,8-dioxyxanthone residue, the photoluminescence of the crown ether ligands was greatly enhanced by complexation of alkaline earth metal ions. Also, no clear emission was observed for trimellitic acid, but its cadmium(II) complex exhibited a strong photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 436 nm upon excitation at 328 nm. Therefore, the observed photoluminescence of complexes 1 and 2 was contributed by the coordination of alkaline earth metal ions to the bta ligands.
